comments.body: If this is a standalone hypervisor, shouldn't the username be `root`? administrator@vsphere.local is not available on a standalone hypervisor

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +67,71 @@  vmware_guest_facts:
    hostname: 192.168.1.209
    username: administrator@vsphere.local
    password: vmware
    datacenter: ha-datacenter

comments.body:
Could this cause backwards compatibility issues?  If someone was relying on the previous behavior of adding the datacenter prefix to searchpath?

I think the approach in this pr is better and more explicit. But I'm not sure if the change will introduce api differences from the 2.3 version though. Would users see a behavior change?

I don't think there will be any backwards compatibility issues with this change. User would not see any behavior change as we are internally changing searchpath. I have added examples for folder path in documentation section which will give a clear idea about this change. 
@jctanner Would you like add something to this ?

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +132,136 @@            vm = find_vm_by_id(self.content, vm_id=uuid, vm_id_type="uuid")
        elif folder:
            searchpath = self.params['folder']

            # get all objects for this path ...

comments.body:
The latest pyVmomi 6.7.1 seems to have tag support without going to REST.  I only have a VCSA in my environment (v6.7).  Perhaps we just need to update pyVmomi and don't need the vCloud / REST requirement here.

When I serialize out the contents of a virtual machine I see this now (with just pyVmomi 6.7.1):
```
    "tag": [
        {
            "dynamicProperty": [], 
            "dynamicType": null, 
            "key": "SYSTEM/COM.VMWARE.VIM.VC"
        }
    ], 
```

OK, does it work for 6.5 and Pyvmomi 6.5 ? I was getting 
```
"tag": []
```

I just tried it with pyVmomi 6.7.1, not sure about any other versions.  Would need to check the pyVmomi project commits to see what's different.  I opened a question for this.  https://github.com/vmware/pyvmomi/issues/733
